key_title: Key to the species of Hibbertia

source.author: Toelken, H.R.
source.title: Dilleniaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Toelken, H.R. (1996). Dilleniaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Stamens surrounding the 3 or rarely 1–5 carpels
Stamens in a single group on one side of the 2 carpels
Ovary glabrous; leaf-base flat and stem-clasping
Ovary hairy; leaf-base raised to some extent in relation to petiole and not stem-clasping
Leaves ± glabrous, cuneate to spathulate, usually lobed at or just below the apex; carpel 1
Carpels 2–5; leaves not as above, when present, lobes irregular and/or not restricted to near the apex
Climber; stamens arranged in a continuous ring around carpels
Prostrate to erect shrubs; stamens in 5 more or less distinct groups around carpels
Leaf-margin indistinct, spreading to incurved; central vein below visible only at the base of lamina
Leaf-margin shortly recurved; central vein visible on much of the lamina
Stems prostrate with distinct internodes; carpels 3–5
Stems erect, spreading or decumbent and without internodes on short shoots; carpels 3
All leaf-axils with long or short shoots
Few leaf-axils with short or long shoots
At least some leaves toothed or lobed; bracts and outer sepals acute
Leaves entire; bracts and outer sepals obtuse to rounded
Branches with simple hairs, or if with few stellate hairs then each hair with fewer than 5 branches
Branches with stellate hairs each with more than 5 branches
Flowers sessile; erect to spreading woody shrubs
Flowers pedunculate; generally procumbent wiry shrublets
Petals less than 8 mm long; vestiture largely non-persistent, plants glabrescent
Petals usually more than 8 mm long; plants hirsute, sometimes only sparsely so, branches and leaves with long simple hairs
Central ridge distant from revolute margins, exposing leaf undersurface; leaves usually more than 4.5 mm long; sepals more than 4.5 mm long
Leaf undersurface completely obscured by the revolute margins; leaves mostly less than 4.5 mm long; sepals less than 4.5 mm long
Vestiture of simple hairs; lower leaf surface ± glabrous
Vestiture of simple and stellate hairs; lower leaf surface stellate-hairy
Branches and undersurface of leaves covered with tubercle-based stellate hairs under larger stalked stellate hairs
Branches and undersurface of leaves covered with more or less similar sized tubercle-based stellate hairs
Leaves with apex obtuse to rounded, rarely acute, lower surface and/or margins with stellate, or stellate and simple hairs
Leaves with pointed or beaked apex, lower surface glabrous or with simple hairs
Flowers pedunculate
Flowers sessile or peduncle less than 3 mm long
Bract below calyx awn-shaped; leaves awned at apex
Bract at base of peduncle blunt; leaves acute at apex with deciduous terminal tuft of hairs
Sepals glabrous; leaves papillose, rarely with rudimentary hairs
Sepals pubescent; leaves pubescent to glabrescent with age
Carpels glabrous; leaf apex beaked and with few terminal hairs
Carpels hairy; leaf apex pointed and with single terminal hair
Leaves otherwise, if linear then at least 5 mm long and usually more than 1 mm wide
Leaves linear, usually less than 6 mm long and 1.3 mm wide
Leaves relatively thin-textured, elliptic to obovate, more or less flat, margins plane to recurved, the lower lamina apparent between the margin and midrib
Leaves thickish,  linear to narrowly elliptic, the lower lamina often more or less obscured by the midrib and revolute margins
Undersurface of leaves densely stellate-hairy with or without scattered hooked simple hairs
Undersurface of leaves sparsely hairy and mainly with hooked simple hairs
Petals shorter than sepals; styles overtopping anthers; branches without simple hairs; upper and lower leaf surfaces with ± equally dense cover of stellate hairs
Petals longer than sepals; styles ± equal to anthers; plants otherwise not as above
Sepals stellate-pubescent, with layer of distinctly longer simple hairs; stamens 10–12
Sepals stellate-pubescent, if ever with scattered longer simple hairs then flowers with less than 9 stamens
Upper surface of adult leaves prominently stellate-hairy; bracts at least half the length of sepals; Wilsons Promontory
Upper surface of adult leaves mostly with simple hairs; bracts usually less than half the length of sepals; Howe Range, far east corner of Victoria
Stamens 4–6(–9); stems usually with some simple hairs; leaves obolanceolate to obovate, mostly up to 7 mm wide (fast-growing young leaves sometimes larger); East Gippsland
Stamens 10–12; stems lacking simple hairs; leaves broad-obovate, usually more than 7 mm wide; near-coastal, west of Cape Otway
Stamens 5–9; at least some stellate hairs present on the central vein on lower surface of leaves, branches, and calyx; simple hairs usually spreading to erect
Stamens 9–12; plants with very few stellate hairs, stellate hairs absent on the central vein; simple hairs usually appressed
Leaves below with central ridge not visibly continued into apex; undersurface visible between central ridge and revolute margins, at least on some leaves
Leaves below with central ridge continued into apex; undersurface often not visible between central ridge and revolute margins
Flowers pedunculate and/or nodding after flowering
Flowers sessile and remaining erect after flowering
Flowers sessile in terminal clusters, rarely on short shoots with leaves, if single then branches pubescent to tomentose
Flowers single, sessile on very short shoots so that they appear to be axillary along the branches; branches almost glabrous
Tufts of hairs between petals and stamens present; flowers surrounded and often hidden by 3–7 bract-like leaves
Tufts of hairs between petals and stamens absent; flowers subtended by, and usually well exceeding 1–few small bracts
Flowers on peduncles more than 5 mm long; plants lacking simple hairs, branches and calyx moderately to densely stellate hairy
Flowers sessile, or if ever on peduncles more than 5 mm long then branches glabrescent or plants with some simple hairs

Plants greyish, pubescent to hirsute; vestiture entirely of stellate hairs (except for tufts of simple hairs in leaf axils), sepals with layers of short and distinctly larger (3–8 times longer) stellate hairs
Plants various, pubescent to glabrescent; vestiture of stellate and/or simple hairs, sepals lacking a layer of distinctly longer (no more than 2 times longer) stellate hairs

Leaves with scattered short, antrorse, few-branched stellate hairs; sepals with long antrorse simple hairs, sometimes with smaller stellate hairs; northern slopes of the Great Dividing Range east of Benalla
Leaves and sepals with erect to spreading stellate or simple hairs, sometimes becoming glabrous
Branches pubescent, or if glabrescent, then with distinct tufts of long hairs in leaf axils; when present, simple hairs on leaves and sepals straight, rarely hooked
Branches sparsely hairy to glabrescent, lacking tufts of long hairs in leaf axils; when present, simple hairs on leaves and sepals usually hooked
Leaves and branches with tubercule-based stellate hairs
Leaves and branches mostly with simple hairs, stellate hairs not tubercule-based, and largely confined to lower leaf surface
